data.question: What is the title of the research article?
data.answer: Redox-Active 1D Coordination Polymers of Iron-Sulfur Clusters

data.question: Who are the authors of the research article?
data.answer: Noah E. Horwitz, Jiaze Xie, Alexander S. Filatov, Robert J. Papoular, William E. Shepard, David Z. Zee, Mia P. Grahn, Chloe Gilder, and John S. Anderson

data.question: What is the DOI of the research article?
What are the main institutions involved in the research?
data.answer: University of Chicago, Saclay Institute for Matter and Radiation, Synchrotron SOLEIL, Northwestern University

data.question: What is the main focus of the research article?
data.answer: The research focuses on the synthesis and characterization of redox-active 1D coordination polymers containing iron-sulfur clusters.

data.question: How does the electrical conductivity change upon reduction of the Fe4S4 clusters in the materials discussed?
data.answer: The introduction of charge carriers by reduction of the Fe4S4 clusters increases the electrical conductivity of the materials by up to 4 orders of magnitude.

data.question: What experimental techniques were used to characterize the coordination polymers?
data.answer: Techniques used include X-ray powder diffraction, small angle X-ray scattering, UV-visible absorption spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, MÃ¶ssbauer spectroscopy, infrared spectroscopy, and electrochemical measurements.

data.question: What is the significance of using Fe4S4 clusters in the synthesis of coordination polymers?
data.answer: Fe4S4 clusters are used due to their redox-activity, stability, electronic delocalization, and complex magnetic features, which are properties also exploited by nature in iron-sulfur proteins.

data.question: True or False: The research article provides a new class of materials based on metal-sulfur clusters with organosulfur ligands for solar fuel catalysis.
What role do modulators play in the synthesis of the coordination polymers mentioned in the research?
data.answer: Modulators control the colloidal stability and polydispersity of the UiO-66 metal-organic framework, suggesting their role in controlling the morphology and solubility of the coordination polymers.
